Richard, NEAT does not normally use backprop because NEAT can evolve 
both =
the topology and weights of the network on its own.  However, it 
can be co=
mbined with backprop if that's what you want to do, and some 
have had succ=
ess with it (as has recently been discussed on this 
group).

As mentioned =
by another poster, my own C++ code has some simple 
experiments such as XOR=
, and to some extent pole balancing is simpler 
than minesweepers.

All the=
 various versions of NEAT, each with their own interesting 
experiments, ar=
e available from my homepage:
http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/

Note howeve=
r that NEAT really wasn't designed for problems like 
multiplexer, which ma=
y be the explanation for your uncertainty.  NEAT 
was designed mostly to de=
al with sparse reinforcement problems (i.e. 
not supervised) that are harde=
r than classification problems where 
targets are provided.  That may be a =
reason that you find the tasks 
available too complex- those are the type o=
f task the system was 
designed for.  Supervised problems are much easier a=
nd the selection 
of methods that can deal with them is greater.

ken

--- =
In neat@yahoogroups.com, Richard Gong <gongrichard@...> wrote:
>
> I'm a no=
ob, and I'm looking at some sharpNEAT code...
> 
> Does NEAT do things like=
 backprop at all? Or does it just randomly 
evolve networks, and combine th=
e best genes? Once you evolve a 
network, and you use backprop on it?
> 
> =
Also, is there a simple NEAT example in c++? (preferably a 
multiplexer or =
something simple, not like smart sweepers)
> 
> Thanks.
> 
> Richard
>
